headline: Great for experience
status:
7 January 2021
"Great for experience"
5.0
★★★★★
Former Employee
pros: A good job for gaining experience. Outside of your typical duties you’ll have limited exposure to clients. The culture is focused on pushing workers to perform at a high level. We’re well supported by all levels of management. Drinking beers on Friday helps to build camaraderie with co-workers.
cons: The long hours are the biggest con.

headline: Not perfect but striving to do better
pros: Not a perfect company by any means. We’ve had our struggles with morale and turnover. The coronavirus hasn’t made these issues any easier. However, AME Group has proven many times over that they’re willing to work on their faults and support their staff to provide a work environment that’s dedicated to their personal and professional growth. Though not perfect, their hearts are in the right place and that’s all that matters to me.
cons: You can look at the other reviews if you want an idea of the cons we’ve struggled with. I see improvements constantly and can only hope and pray that we continue to strive to do better as a company.

headline: Employees always come first
status:
11 December 2020
"Employees always come first"
5.0
★★★★★
Former Employee
pros: Employees are treated with the respect and dignity they’re due. Being part of a research team is often one of the best ways to learn because younger engineers are paired with senior consultants who provide mentorship and guidance. It’s a well-structured operation that can help you to get your career off the ground.
cons: Pay isn’t the best. No one would complain if the idea of pay raises were floated out there however.

headline: Strong management at the top
status:
1 December 2020
"Strong management at the top"
5.0

Current Employee
pros: The management are forward facing innovative individuals who are constantly striving towards excellence. There are opportunities to build a career if that’s something you truly want. Management are always on the lookout for the most dedicated employees when it comes time to promote someone. Nothing is given to you. You have to work for what you want.
cons: Communication across offices has its challenges.
advice_to_mgmt: You don’t need me to tell you what you need to work on. Focus on your weak points and make the necessary changes.

headline: An amazing company
status:
23 November 2020
"An amazing company"
5.0
★★★★★
Current Employee
pros: If you’re willing and able to invest your energy into working at AME you won’t be sorry. You get an in-depth look into the mining industry that most people don’t get to typically see. Management is always a pleasure to work with. They expect you to work hard, so as long as you’re doing your job and pulling your weight you shouldn’t encounter any problems.
cons: This is a high-pressure environment that will eventually begin to wear on you.
advice_to_mgmt: Ignore the naysayers. Continue to strive towards the future and do right by your employees.

cons: The training of new hires needs to be more thorough. Morale is an issue that needs to be addressed.
advice_to_mgmt: You’re making strides in the right direction, but there’s room for improvement.

status:
1 November 2020
Helpful (1)
"Fantastic work environment"
5.0
★★★★★
Current Employee
pros: This is a company that’s always shifting and evolving to meet the needs of the market. Rarely are we stagnant. This comes with the benefits of staying present with the times, but with the cons of employees lashing out because it’s human nature to resist change. As we sit now, the company is in a great place and I pray that we continue to operate successfully as we move into a new year.
cons: High turnover is an issue because it’s hard to meet managerial expectations.
advice_to_mgmt: Pay more attention to morale. If you sense people aren’t happy take quick and decisive action to remedy the issue.

headline: Management should be embarrassed. Fraudulent. Shockingly low benchmark for work quality. Horrible treatment of staff.
status:
8 December 2019
Helpful (19)
"Management should be embarrassed. Fraudulent. Shockingly low benchmark for work quality. Horrible treatment of staff."
1.0
★★★★★
Former Employee
pros: The fact that I can write this review and empathise with what others have written here. Years later I still think back to how terribly run the business was/is (clearly still the case based on what is written here).
cons:
Shaun Browne is a pathalogical liar. His word is worthless. Not only does he completely overstate his own experience and knowledge base but he must be deluded, regarding AME's standing in the industry. 

Any time an actually knowledgable or competent staff member (very few of these as all AME does is hire, and then overwork/underpay inexperienced staff), proposed (or heaven forbid proactively pursued) real anaysis Shaun would reject the suggestion.....borne out of ego and a deep mistrust for his staff. 

In my time since work at AME (approx 5yrs ago) I have gone on to work in other commoditiy based business and EVERY person I have ever spoken about having worked at AME either A) laughed and we shared stories about the time they worked there to or B) they expressed genuine disbelief at how poor the work from AME is

I laugh now whenever I see material from AME in my day to day. Many times I have actively recommended businesses I am associated with NOT to use AME simply due to its exceptionally poor standard of work.

It is amazing to me the company still has clients. The level of useful, insightful analysis behind the work is shockingly low and out of date. The number of times embarrassing errors were pointed out by clients was endless.
advice_to_mgmt:
Read these review. Take it on board. Maybe aim for some self improvement. They are written by honest, smart people that you treated poorly. Your reputation in the industry is permantently damaged. 

And how funny are the comments being posted to these reviews? Nothing more clearly demonstrates the management's mind set than the feeble attempts to discredit what a clearly genuine experiences.

cons: While I got along with most of the colleagues at this place there is this underlying tension here that you’d have to cut with a steak knife it’s so thick. The chief is probably one of the most paranoid people I’ve ever worked for, there was a security camera on my floor that was watching people while they worked, which is illegal by the way. I also noticed that one of the administrators would go around to peoples desks and do a kinda roll call making sure everyone was at work, kinda like being back in primary school. Not allowed to send external emails as well which I found strange.
advice_to_mgmt: I can totally understand that you need to protect your intellectual property in order to run this business however I have serious concerns about the mental health of upper management due to the strange behaviour that I witnessed while working here. A corporate psychologist would have a field day with AME.

headline: Career destroyer! Think twice before joining.

1. Micro-management - half hourly timesheet to fill everyday
2. Workload - expect you to work crazy hour and it's called becoming an expert so you should do this for free
3. Resource - lacking and shocking! Each analyst is doing 2/3 people workload. 
4. Career progression - none unless you can make money for the company.
5. Over promised - always yes to clients even though it is not deliverables. Creative thinking is highly desireable and rewarded!
6. Holiday - 2-3 week compulsory holidays (depend which regional office) over Xmas when it is the quietest period. What can I say? Just do not expect holiday any other time.
7. No analysis - no time for quality analysis. Purely data cruching and desktop research. Clients loves us because they outsource their work to us and we cannot say no.
advice_to_mgmt: Stuff turnover for around a year or often less tell you something!

headline: If the staff engagement strategy comprises fake reviews on social media, it speaks volumes of the workplace culture.
status:
6 January 2021
Helpful (2)
"If the staff engagement strategy comprises fake reviews on social media, it speaks volumes of the workplace culture."
1.0
★★★★★
Former Employee
pros:
AME is a well-trodden path from the technical world into financial services. Many have used it as a short stepping stone and done well. A larger number have slipped and died professionally whilst trying.

Depending on the role, some people get the opportunity to meet a lot of people in the industry. It’s a very steep learning curve and some of the on-the-job training for juniors is excellent, albeit self directed.

The company is always hiring. It’s not growing, you’re just being interviewed to replace the last person who was pushed out or got fed up and resigned.
cons:
There’s a reason it’s only a stepping stone. It’s a hell hole of a place to work. About 50% of staff don’t make it through the first twelve months either failing probation or being made ‘redundant’. You should only ever accept a position with AME if you are not working and consider it a short term stint whilst you look for something else.

They pay is lousy for what is expected and the work hours are long. Contractual hours are 830am to 6pm with an hour for lunch, or 42.5 hours per week. However leaving at 6pm is frowned upon. One well-known but unwritten KPI is the time you leave. In reality, junior staff should expect to work a 45-50 hour week, and more senior staff 50-55 hours per week. Every week. A call with a client in London can mean you won’t get out of the office until 9pm. There’s no time in lieu, it’s back to the office at 830 the next morning. AME is particularly difficult for people with family commitments.

The horrendous staff turnover saps efficiency and contributes to the longer hours. Efficiency and quality is reduced by forever training new people to do the same thing. For those staff that do manage to hold on to their job, the job satisfaction is low as you can never break free of the tedium. It’s also demoralising watching your friends and colleagues be bullied and sacked one after the other.

The most vile part of AME is the toxic, back-stabbing culture that stems from the owner. He cannot relate to people and has big problems with trust. He can’t be trusted and he trusts no-one. It’s a vicious cycle. He’s convinced that every member of staff is inherently lazy and will do nothing given the opportunity. Every control system (e.g. internal office CCTV, email monitoring, keystroke logging, work hour recording) plays into this his obsession that staff are stealing (time). All decisions and expenses however small go across his desk.

At the same time, staff don’t trust management, and rightfully so given the frequent lies and u-turns. There is no honesty between staff and management. Anyone who objects to the company direction-du-jour will just end up being the next person in line to be bullied until they resign or be ‘retrenched’. Being too committed to one direction might find you favour temporarily, but once the wind changes you’re exposed.

Management is utterly ineffective and concentrated with the owner. Formal management structures have been dissolved and change on a whim. All are designed to play staff off against one another and feed information on supposed individual staff underperformance back to the owner.
advice_to_mgmt: If you don’t want Glass Door sit at the top of the Google results when someone searches for AME, stop placing fake reviews. The more often a page is updated, the higher in the search results it is placed by the search engine algorithms. The bland and unrealistic positive reviews invite more comments from staff who would otherwise be silent.

headline: Nothing changes
status:
31 August 2018
Helpful (42)
"Nothing changes"
1.0
★★★★★
Former Employee
pros: Racked my brains, can’t think of a single positive
cons:
I worked at AME a few years ago, so to see the current crop of (very) negative reviews is simultaneously unsurprising and remarkable. Remarkable because it seems as though nothing has changed in all these years. 

Still sounds like Shaun Browne is bullying and mistreating people.

The atmosphere still sounds toxic.

The culture of the organization is still riven with problems caused by Shaun.

The quality of the work still sounds like it is very materially compromised by the extraordinarily high staff turnover, the lack of development and a leadership team that have absolutely no idea about the mining industry. 

Indeed I was often put in a position of either having to lie to clients about what work had been done, or having to profusely apologize for the substandard quality of the work, all while “the leadership” actually hid (and I mean actually physically hid). 

My time at AME was an eye opening experience, to see how an organisation should not be run and to work for someone I believe to be a genuinely unpleasant individual. 

I would caution anyone thinking about accepting a job here to reconsider and also recommend that organisations considering engaging AME for work to think about the quality of output they require.

cons:
1. The management level put all employee in high presure on each task and time frame.

3. The management level did calculate/book employee's toilet, coffee,lunch and morning arrive time etc.. Did see someone get warning for these. 
4. The office building is pool and old. All facilities are very pool. it Only got 2-3 toilets for whole building which are always broken.

response:
Thanks for your feedback. Just to clear a few things up:
- AME's hours are 8:30am - 6:00pm (with a 1 hour lunch break) which are the normal operating hours of any business (not sure if you've had a job before?) 
- We have 5 modern and fully functional bathrooms 
- We are lucky enough to work in a huge, spacious building (wood floors, huge glass windows, massive ceiling height and exposed brick walls - which is the very coveted New York loft style - I'm guessing interior design isn't your thing)
- We don't calculate lunch/breaks/bathroom time (obviously) but we note arrival and departure time for the day, like every other business in the world (again, i'm not sure if you've ever had a job before?)
We wish you all the best for the future.

headline: This is the one review to rule them all
status:
8 August 2017
Helpful (54)
"This is the one review to rule them all"
1.0
★★★★★
Former Employee
pros: I got to write the cons on Glassdoor when I left. These reviews are smuggled into the office like western media into North Korea. These reviews give the poor souls still trapped there hope for the future. Plus they are also good for a laugh on Friday when you get beer. Oh look. A single. Realistic. Pro.
cons:
This website has said a great deal about AME. I don’t see any point in repeating what has already been said by past employees. It clearly doesn’t stop people from entering through the door for an interview. Therefore, the aim of this review is to stop people from even bothering to apply for anything posted by this company.

The worst thing about this company is not the physically demanding hours and pathetic excuse for a wage (although these two reasons are pretty bad). No, the worst thing about this company is how it will change you psychologically. It will warp you. It will corrupt you. The perverse nature of simply existing within these walls will destroy you. And the worst part is you won’t even notice it. Not until you tell friends. You’ll even joke about. You’ll say something like…

“Someone else got fired today. It’s the third one this month. And they’ve only been here for two days! Then gone, poof. I didn’t even bother remembering their name. I don’t bother remembering anyone’s name unless they’ve been here for over a month”. Then you’ll probably laugh. HAHAHAHAHA.

Your friends will be shocked. They’ll probably say something like. “I can’t believe such a terrible place exists. You have to leave”. And you’ll just shrug it off. Maybe you’ll blame the terrible job market. Or maybe you'll point out the fact that rent doesn’t pay itself. However, it doesn’t change the fact you laughed.

Think about it. You laughed, you mocked someone in the exact same situation as you. They also exist in a terrible job market and I bet they have to pay rent too. You saw someone in the same terrible situation as you and you joked and laughed at their misery. 

Aren’t you also miserable? Of course you are. You work at AME. Why are you laughing at someone in the exact same situation as you? Would you laugh a homeless person on the street? Or someone lying on a hospital bed? I know the laughter is ironic. It is the cynical snickering that comes from black humour. Everyone here shares the same fate. United in adversity, as you will read in all the other reviews. But ask yourself. Right now. As someone who has not been tainted by AME. Would you laugh if someone else got fired for doing nothing wrong in their first few days? If you’re already at AME, it is too late. But hey, at least there’s beer on Friday right? 

And this is why AME is so terrible. It is so cancerous that it strips you of basic human compassion. If you work here you will no longer be able to look at people as if they were actually people. New people are just sacrifices, a fresh batch of souls cooking in the oven for the CEO. Working here will remove something that is basically ingrained into you at birth because you cannot believe something so perversely inhumane (the CEO) has the audacity to assume the form of a normal functioning human being.

Beware the wolf in sheep’s clothing. If he’s charming to you in the interview (if you even get what could pass off as an interview), press the Glassdoor button. He will be so flustered you’ll think English is his second language. He might even get out some paper and draw a lot of diagrams to prove god knows what.
advice_to_mgmt:
How to Make a Painkiller (Cocktail)

2 oz Pusser's rum
4 oz Pineapple juice
1 oz Orange juice
1 oz Cream of coconut
Grated Nutmeg
Pineapple Wedge

1. Add all of the ingredients into a shaker and fill with ice.
2. Shake vigorously and strain into a hurricane glass or snifter filled with crushed ice.
3. Garnish with freshly grated nutmeg and a pineapple wedge.

Reading this recipe was a complete waste of your time and an excellent showcase of what it feels like working at this company. However, if you ignore my many warnings and accept an offer here, please use this recipe to deal with the crippling physical and psychological damage you will receive.
response: Thank you for your feedback. We understand that leaving fictitious Glassdoor reviews has become a favoured hobby of yours. You're clearly very comical and have a love of outrageous storytelling. May I suggest a career in stand up or the theatre? I think your talents are being wasted in the resources industry. We wish you all the best for the future.

★★★★★
Former Employee
pros: Your colleagues are generally decent and united in the shared disrespect of Shaun Brown.
cons:
The problems with AME lie directly with the owner, Shaun Browne. At best, his management is comically awful with compulsive decision making, value-destroying about-turns and a child-like understanding of the technical aspects of the mining and oil and gas industries. At worst, Shaun Browne is a chronic bully - mentally, verbally and physical. He appears to contrive tension by pitting staff against each other. Senseless personnel changes are ongoing and poorly communicated. You could suddenly be reporting to someone else or, unbeknownst to you, people reporting to you could suddenly be reporting to a different colleague. 
Shaun Browne has a Trump-like ego and is blithely unaware of his own ineptitude. He has owned this business for over 25 years and literally knows nothing else outside those four walls. It is painfully obvious to even the youngest of analysts who have worked in professionally-run organisations that he is quite clueless. Unfortunately this makes Shaun Browne quite condescending and will constantly remind the staff that he has "being doing this longer than anyone else" and considers that justification for his poor decision making.
If you’re going for a BD role, do not expect to last for longer than 6 months. Otherwise, if you show any initiative you will be exploited mercilessly and dumped after a couple of years. The office is made up with those trying to work out what is going and those that are trying to leave. Do not fall for his faux charm and self-deprecation - it is fake as the positive reviews he organises for this site.
advice_to_mgmt: It is painfully obvious, to both employees and clients, how bad a job you're doing. Stop kidding yourself about getting PE on board and wind it up.
response: Thanks for your feedback. In order to remain competitive, innovative and continue to provide our clients with the best technical site reviews and valuations in the world, we have shifted away from non-technical people, such as yourself, and are now only seeking technically qualified, resources experienced staff members. We apologise for the distress this has caused you and wish you all the best finding another job.

headline: Glassdoor for Sale
status:
7 July 2017
Helpful (38)
"Glassdoor for Sale"
1.0
★★★★★
Current Employee
pros: Everyday is one day closer to death! If you can last more than a year at AME, that is worth putting on your Resume.
cons:
DO NOT BELIEVE ANY POSITIVE POSTS ABOUT AME!!

The only thing worse than working at AME is knowing that AME can pay third party companies, or even Glassdoor itself to remove some of the negative posts and place higher weighting to positive comments, that have been clearly written by the owner or his immediate family. I have previously been tasked with signing up to 'Internet Reputation' companies that we pay to try to improve our image on Glassdoor.

If you are applying for a Business Development or Human Resources position, don't bother! I my 2 years here I have not seen anyone last more than 4 months, most last only a week or so.

Turnover here is huge, circa 60-70% per year. The people that stay (myself included) are either brainwashed, have limited opportunities elsewhere due to the market, or are just starting out and need to prove themselves.

There are no perks, the owner of the company tries to be charming but once you're there he will dictate every aspect of your employment down to the colour short you wear, where you will sit (which changes weekly), and he even tries to interfere with people's personal lives. To say the owner is a micromanager is the understatement of the year.

Nightmares will become commonplace. Long hours are expected. You will be given 10 times the amount of work that would normally be expected. Your job title will change monthly and if you are good at your job, he will pile more and more work on that person until they break. It is heartbreaking to see because these are some of the best people I have ever worked with. Without the owners constant interfering and crazy behaviour, this company could go places. Unfortunately the company remains stagnant, always trying to replace lost staff, instead of focussing on what it's good at.

Please do not accept a job here unless you have absolutely no choice. But if you do, to sum up a post put up here about a year ago, you will find we are 'together in adversity!'

Contact current or ex-staff to confirm all this.
advice_to_mgmt: Remove the owner from the day to day operations of this company and maybe there would be a chance for this company to succeed and for the culture to improve. But even his trusty sidekick is no better. If for 25 years you haven't found out what the problem is, then maybe it's you!
response: Thank you for your feedback. We're sorry to hear you don't feel appreciated as we work hard to provide our clients with a great working environment and career growth opportunities. We understand that you're upset but instead of writing fictitious slander, please come and talk to us! We always want our employees to feel valued and enthusiastic about their role. Work/life balance is really important to us at AME, which is why we never work weekends and have a closing time of 6pm - which is rare in our competitive industry. Innovation and product development is at the top of our priority list - always has been and always will be. We are expanding rapidly and hope you join us on our fantastic new path. And, if not, we wish you all the best for the future.

It's a very thin veneer, as soon as you're onboard he shows himself to be the slimy, arrogant and downright abusive snake that he is. If you don't sink into the background, you will get fired. Please, do yourself a favour and avoid AME, you are better than this company.
advice_to_mgmt: Be upfront and honest about what you want, learn about modern business practices, outsource to a decent marketing company, stop deluding yourself with this nonsense about being two years behind Google, having better programming than Microsoft etc. In reality you're not even close to the standard we've seen from your competitors and are unlikely to ever really be competition to them.

headline: Great People in a Fast Moving Space
status:
3 March 2017
Helpful (4)
"Great People in a Fast Moving Space"
4.0
★★★★★
Current Employee
pros:
I have been working at AME London for a couple of years and enjoy the fast pace and changing environment, as well as the forward looking nature of management who are always setting challenging but innovative goals! 
Excellent travel opportunities and ability to gain more responsibility extremely fast if you want it. You get to work with a tight team of intelligent people who are experts in their sector and enjoy what they do. 
You also get to interact with a huge range of clients and have a real input into a machine that sets tight targets to grow completely new and independent tools based on the newest computing technology.
cons: Working tightly and communicating with global offices can be difficult, but this is manageable. You can travel significantly, but you do have scope to mitigate this.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep the innovation & product development moving forward on the path its going, Continue to set the trend on the technology and AI side of research.

headline: The bottom rung
pros:
- The middle and lower levels of management (industry directors and your immediate manager and advisors) will explain your work with you clearly and help you learn whatever systems you may need to master to do your job to the best of your ability
- Camaraderie is strong in the face of adversity
- If you have a tough skin and know how to lick managerial boots, you will likely succeed here
- When the boss is overseas, the environment improves immensely and you may do your job well
- If you're starting out on the path of your career, this is a good stepping stone—so long as you only stay here as long as is respectable with regards to your resume
- Some positions allow you to clock off at your contracted time and leave your work at work (although, most expect overtime on an almost daily basis)
- If you do your job well and help others wherever possible, you will likely make firm friends through respect and trust
cons:
- The boss doesn't know where the company is going (or if he does know where he wants it to go, he can't make up his mind how to get there, so be prepared to work your fingers off on a whim of his, to then have all that work disregarded the next week, to then be forced to focus on something else)
- You will get intimidated by the boss on a daily basis, whether he's in the office or overseas
- High turnover rate of staff, due to dissatisfaction with the work environment, intimidation, stress and lack of respect shown by upper management, which means you will likely have to make friends quickly, and see them leave soon after
- Quantity is valued over quality, so don't expect to do your best work here
- Staff members are overworked and not remunerated for extra efforts or overtime
- Culture of backstabbing and mistrust is rampant
- Family-run business, so the boss thinks he's a king and you are his servants
- Do not expect your suggestions to be taken seriously—you are there to carry out orders, no matter how illogical they may be
- The boss will charm you into thinking he values your opinions, but he doesn't, he simply wants to deceive you about his true character—but you will learn in time and through experience
- If you are considering work experience here as part of a degree, be prepared for a hard slog—you will be treated terribly, the system will not be explained to you in full and you will likely walk away from the experience with a warped view of the industry
- Do not take a job here unless you have no other choice

Any rating over two stars for this company and its boss are likely written by management. Do not trust any reviews that claim the environment is stimulating and creative or that you have opportunities to grow in this company. You do not, unless you have the same manipulative personality as its owner. Work outside of your contract will be thrust upon you but you will not thrive or be rewarded for extra duties.

This is not a 'disgruntled' ex-worker's review. This is an honest review, with a mind to warn anyone who may be considering a position here. Weigh up your options very carefully.
advice_to_mgmt:
- Management would do well to respect those who have come to work for them and to not treat them like 'things' that they own.
- Planning could be greatly improved upon to reduce time wasted on whimsical projects.
- Environment could be greatly improved upon by encouraging friendly interaction between all rungs of the business, perhaps through social events or worker perks.
response: Thanks for your feedback. We're sorry to hear you didn't enjoy your time at AME as we work hard to ensure a fantastic work environment for all our employees by offering generous salary, support and training, career growth opportunities, work/life balance with a closing time of 6pm (very rare in our competitive industry) and interesting work. We provide our clients with the best technical site reviews and valuations in the world so we deeply care about quality not quantity - in fact, it is what we are known for. For a confidential discussion please feel free to contact ame@amegroup.com. We wish you all the best for the future.

headline: Fast-paced and competitive
pros:
AME has a highly competitive outfit; with lean business units in all cities it has office. It is flexible and fast-paced, constantly re-structuring and modernizing. 
Executive management sets the strategy (milestones and targets) to each research manager. These carry precise expectations regarding schedule and budget. At the same time there is great autonomy on how to conduct the research.
Typically research teams will have young engineers supporting senior consultants with lots of field experience. So work provides many opportunities to meet experts in the field, but is also lively and full of young ambitious people. Friday beers are almost like a religion.
Working hours are normal. But the environment extremely fast-paced and targets are always set to challenge the team. Improving productivity, quality and developing new products dominate management agenda since I joined. Ruthless pursuit for improvement that can be contagious, especially because management is fast in identifying and promoting good workers/ideas. But if you are not a competitive self-motivated person, this might not be the place for you. I have seen plenty of turnovers related to this mentality.
If you are highly driven, the learning curves are astonishing. Even though each team deals with training in their own way, engineering and economic experience abound. There is always an area of expertise new employees don’t have experience with, be it the economic valuation / marketing strategy, or the technical engineering side of natural resource projects.
cons:
AME is a family-owned business, this means decision making is fast and responsive but also very concentrated on the Executive Director. 
Part of IT is outsourced which is not ideal. 
For field engineers going into research, pay is not ideal.
They have coffee but it is terrible, bring your own.
advice_to_mgmt: Improved transparency on individual business units financial results. Making staff minority partners could improve pay, motivation and retention.
response: Thanks for your feedback. We're so glad to hear you are enjoying our flexible, fast-paced and productive work environment. We are grateful to have so many fantastic employees, such as yourself, who are committed to, and have a love for, innovative product development and the quest to constantly improve quality - as this is the heart of what we do. We can't wait to see what the future holds for you at AME.
